prompts.prompt: The Bakufu decided to close Japan to most foreigners. What were they worried about? Think about: What were European missionaries doing in Japan? Why did that scare the Bakufu?
rubric: European missionaries (especially Portuguese) were converting Japanese people to Christianity
A large number of Japanese (about 150,000) had converted, mainly in the Nagasaki area
The Bakufu feared Christianity would threaten their power and the social order
European nations had taken over (colonized) other parts of Asia, and Japan didn't want to be next

prompts.prompt: The Closed Country Edict of 1635 had strict rules. Name as many rules as you can remember. Think about: What happened to Japanese people who tried to leave? What happened to Christianity? What about foreigners already in Japan?
rubric: No Japanese person could leave the country (penalty of death)
No Japanese living abroad could come back to Japan
Christianity had to be wiped out
People who reported Christian priests would be rewarded
Foreign ships had to be checked for hidden priests

prompts.prompt: In Edo Japan, merchants were near the bottom of the social hierarchy — even though many were rich! Why were they ranked so low? Think about: What did Edo Japan think was more important than money? What did merchants actually do compared to farmers?
rubric: The social hierarchy was based on Confucian values — how much you contributed to society, not how rich you were
Merchants didn't produce anything — they just bought and sold goods that others made
Farmers and artisans ranked higher because they actually produced food and useful things
This shows Edo Japan valued contribution and loyalty over personal wealth

prompts.prompt: The Bakufu had many clever rules to stop the daimyo (feudal lords) from becoming too powerful. Describe as many of these rules as you can. Think about: Where did daimyo have to live? What couldn't they build? Who couldn't they talk to?
rubric: Daimyo had to spend every second year living in Edo (sankin-kotai), which kept them watched and drained their money
Only one castle was allowed per domain, so they couldn't build up military strength
No contact was allowed between daimyo, to stop them forming alliances against the Shogun
Daimyo needed the Bakufu's permission to get married
Daimyo had to pay for public building projects, which kept them from saving up money

prompts.prompt: Edo Japan had two levels of government. Describe each one. Think about: What was the local level called and who ran it? What was the central level called and who ran it? Where did the Emperor fit in?
rubric: The Han was the local level — each domain was run by its own daimyo
The Bakufu was the central government, run by the Shogun from Edo
The Bakufu was in charge of all the han and could make laws that daimyo had to follow
The Emperor was only a figurehead — he had a spiritual role but no real political power

prompts.prompt: During the Edo period, arts like Kabuki theatre, woodblock prints, and Bunraku puppets became really popular. Why did culture grow so much during this time? Think about: Was Japan at war or peace? What happened in the cities? Who had time and money for entertainment?
rubric: Japan was at peace for a long time, so people had more free time for fun and creativity
Cities grew larger and the merchant class became wealthy, creating demand for entertainment
Daimyo and wealthy people became patrons of the arts, paying for cultural activities
Woodblock printing made art and books cheaper, so more people could enjoy them

prompts.prompt: The Dutch were the only Western country allowed to trade with Japan during isolation, and they had to stay on Deshima island. Why were the Dutch allowed in? And why was Deshima a smart choice for the Bakufu?
rubric: The Dutch only wanted to trade — unlike the Portuguese and Spanish, they didn't bring missionaries or try to spread Christianity
Deshima was a man-made (artificial) island, so the Bakufu said it wasn't really Japanese soil
This let Japan get the benefits of trade while still saying they were keeping foreigners out

prompts.prompt: Three leaders worked together (over time) to unify Japan: Oda Nobunaga, Toyotomi Hideyoshi, and Tokugawa Ieyasu. What did each one do? Think about: Who started it? Who created the tax and class systems? Who finished it and became Shogun?
rubric: Oda Nobunaga started unification by conquering territories and building castles
Toyotomi Hideyoshi continued by creating the koku tax system (based on rice) and freezing the social classes
Tokugawa Ieyasu finished unification by winning the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600
Ieyasu became Shogun in 1603 and set up the Tokugawa Shogunate with Edo as the capital

prompts.prompt: Even though Japan was 'closed,' foreign ideas still got in! How did outside knowledge reach Japan during isolation? Think about: Who traded at Deshima? What did they teach the Japanese? Were there any other countries still allowed in?
rubric: The Dutch traded from Deshima island and shared knowledge, especially about medicine and surgery
Chinese and Korean traders were also allowed limited access to Japan
Chinese influence actually grew stronger during this time because their goods and ideas were among the few allowed in
Dutch doctors taught Japanese scholars new medical techniques that changed how they understood the human body

prompts.prompt: Edo Japan had three big important cities: Edo, Kyoto, and Osaka. What was each city known for? Think about: Which one was the government centre? Which was the cultural/imperial capital? Which was the business hub?
rubric: Edo was where the Shogun ruled from — it was the centre of the military government
Kyoto was the old imperial capital where the Emperor lived, known for culture and luxury goods
Osaka was the economic centre, called the 'kitchen of Japan' because of its famous markets
Osaka set the standard price for rice across all of Japan
